question: He came to the town of magic and dreams a flashing star blazing through the firmament of illusion. And he promised to devour the world in a single gulp. He was 24 years old and his name was George Orson Welles. Sound the trumpets! Unfurl the banners, Hollywood! The Boy Wonder has arrived! He made his debut on the world stage in Kenosha, Wisconsin, on the 6th of May, 1915. And on the 7th of May he spoke his first words, and unlike other children who say commonplace things like "momma" and "poppa", he proclaimed "I am a genius!" So how could the magic of the stage not call to this adventurous lad? Unstoppable and resolute, the Boy Wonder journeyed into the world of the legit theater. After a peripatetic beginning he found himself at last in New York where he joined forces with theatrical producer John Houseman under the august auspices of the WPA Federal Theater. Like Hannibal over the Alps, the Boy Genius invaded the Great White Way. He stunned the sedate elite of New York theatre with production after production. From MACBETH with an entirely colored cast to a Mussolini-inspired JULIUS CAESAR! Though he wowed the critics with his spectaculars the ticket sales left something to be desired. So, after founding the Mercury Players with Houseman, young Mr. Welles quickly set his sights on the airwaves. He quickly became the sonorous -' voice of "The Shadow." ''
answer: Who knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men? The Shadow knows. . .

question: With Lament Cranston in one pocket and his own radio show. The Mercury Theater of the Air, our Boy Wonder filled the night with his resounding tones. And on October 30th of 1938, he became what he felt destined to be THE WAR OF THE WORLDS sent this nation spinning into a frenzy. Nine million listeners clasped their loved ones close and looked to the skies with horror. Unlucky listeners near the epicenter of the "invasion" -- rural New Jersey -- ran screaming into the night, sure a monstrous alien and a fiery death awaited them around every corner! The mischievous Boy Wonder had fooled us all!
answer: Of course ... of course ... if I had known the panic the broadcast was causing -- well I would have stopped! I never meant for any of this to happen and I feel just horrible!

question: I don't know what you expected with Joseph- fucking-Conrad for Chrissake. I mean this is Hollywood, pal.
answer: All right! Enough! I've heard this from Schaefer and RKO. I've heard it from everyone--

question: But you keep coming up with the same elitist crap - - HEART OF DARKNESS with a million dollar budget?! - - no one wants to see that.
answer: Nonsense

question: What are movies about, Orson?
answer: Forget it-

question: What are movies about?
answer: Telling stories.

question: Nope.
answer: Showing life

question: Who the hell wants to see life?! People are sick to death of life! They want make-believe, pal. Fantasy. They want Tarzan and Jane, not Tristan and Isolde.
answer: Magic

question: Butts on seats. That's what movies are about. You got one job in Hollywood -- everyone has the same job, in fact -- putting the butts on the seats. You gotta sell 'em popcorn and Pepsi- cola. It's all about popcorn and Pepsi-cola.
answer: Not for me.

question: Then you better get ready to be the youngest never- was in Hollywood history.
answer: That's better than being the oldest has-been in Hollywood history.

question: You're a laugh-riot, kid.
answer: Here, turn around. So, we've got to come up with our movie. Our biography.

question: Right-
answer: We find the man and then we dissect him-

question: Like a bug.
answer: But with compassion and insight--

question: Christ, we gotta go! The old man doesn't cotton to lateness.
answer: How do you do, Mr. Hearst? My name is Orson Welles. How about Howard Hughes? We could do Hughes

question: I'm not fucking with Hughes. That shit-kicker would kill us dead, baby. Just like Jean Harlow
answer: Howard Hughes killed Jean Harlow?

question: Sigmund Freud?
answer: Kid, you just got your ass kicked on Joseph Conrad and now you're gonna go to Schaefer and tell him you wanna do the id and the superego? Stop being so goddamn smart.

question: Manolete?!
answer: Who the hell's Manolete?

question: The great Spanish bullfighter
answer: I don't wanna write about no spic.

question: No, it's perfect! When in doubt, put on a cape! False noses and faux beards and flowing capes have been the life-blood of the actor's craft since the days of lrving and Booth. Imagine me in a glittering suit of lights on the dusky Andalusian plains--
answer: Why Mr. Welles is attempting semaphore

question: Bullfighting, Miss Davies!
answer: And is dear Mank your b-b-bull?

question: My father and I made a tour of the grand boulevards of antique Europe. And when we were in Iberia I had the chance to face the bulls. At the knee of the great Manolete I took up the cape and sword - -- across from me stood a mammoth bull reputed to have gored a full seven men to a grisly demise! So - - with Manolete shouting encouragement I flourished . . . I flourished again . . . and the bull charged! Across the golden dust it came, thundering like the great minotaur of legend, closer, ever closer, its calamitous hooves pounding into the dirt, shaking the earth as I held the crimson eye of the bull with my own, defying it -- it was almost upon me and I flourished one last time! -- the monster swept past!
answer: You are evidently a man who knows a great deal about bull. Of all man's malignity -- of all his sadism -- none is more depraved than cruelty to animals.

question: In Spain the cruelty would be in denying the beast a fighting end.
answer: Who are you, sir?

question: My name is Orson Welles
answer: The actor

question: And director.
answer: I see. And you are in California for what reason?

question: To make pictures.
answer: And what pictures have you made?

question: None.
answer: Well, I wish you luck. It is a treacherous business.

question: So I've been told.
answer: In Hollywood the fiercest bulls are the most brutally killed.

question: The man doesn't allow drinking or cigars? This is monstrous.
answer: The old man has his own way of doing things

question: He's nothing but a hypocrite. He preaches morality every day in his sordid little papers for everyone else in the world but he lives openly with his mistress.
answer: Buddy, when you own the largest publishing empire in the universe you can do whatever the hell you want. Think about it, pal. Every day one out of five Americans picks up a Hearst publication. 30 newspapers, a dozen magazines, a bunch of radio stations and the grand dragon of them all. Little Miss Louella Parsons. Tends to give you some of that ol' noblesse oblige.

question: Look at those hands. Those are the hands of an artist. A modern Caravaggio.
answer: No, baby, those are the hands of a killer

question: God, these parties are the worst
answer: You need to get outta here, Rapunzel

question: That's why he has the parties, he says it's like bringing the world to me.
answer: Why don't you come down to LA? Stay with us for a while.

question: With about twenty of his spies on my tail. No thanks. It's not so bad here. After all, what girl doesn't want to live in a castle? Mr. Welles certainly is a caution
answer: Yeah, Orson's a real piece of work. But deep down, he's a good kid. Real deep down.

question: And attractive in a hammy sort of way.
answer: Mm. Listen, you come down and stay with us for a few days. Just tell the old man that--

question: I can't
answer: Sure you can, just--

question: Yeah, it's the place God would have built, if he'd had the money.
answer: Mankie, Mankie d-d-dance with me

answer: Shit, can you smell it? You got any sen-sen?

question: Sorry.
answer: Mr. Welles, you got any--? Oh fuck it.

question: It's gonna be fine, Orson. You're gonna do great.
answer: I wonder sometimes.

question: You're just scared.
answer: Am I? And what am I scared of?

question: Of being found out. Of not being a genius
answer: Oh, but haven't you heard? I'm the Boy Wonder. I've been a genius since the moment I was born.

question: We've known each other too long, Orson. Sling the bullshit elsewhere.
answer: Carole, you wound me! As if I could hope to pacify you with evasions of--

question: Mank! You scoundrel! What took you so long?!
answer: Orson, please ... it's too bright

question: Here you are, up with the birds for once, you vampire!
answer: Okay, boy wonder, what?

question: Listen ... I've got it! It came to me like a thief in the night! Pure inspiration! Total magnificence!
answer: Oh for Christ's sake-

question: I know who we're going to get I The great American biography! A journey into the soul of the beast.
answer: This better be good

question: Image a man that has shaped his time. A titanic figure of limitless influence. Think about empire. A man with an empire at his feet. A man, like a baron, living in a palace, a glorious palace on a hill, and controlling the permutations of everyone beneath him. Feudal.
answer: Oh Christ...

question: Image the possibilities as this man controls the public perception of the nation through his--
answer: Oh Christ

question: Yes.
answer: Please don't say this.

question: Mank-
answer: Don't whisper it. Don't even think it

question: How long have we spent casting our minds about the world when the answer to our prayers was right here under our noses -- every single day in the newspapers and on the radio -- waiting for us in that ridiculous castle! Waiting for--!
answer: Orson. Stop. Just stop

question: Now remember he's a public figure who sought out that publicity so legally he can't stop us from--
answer: Listen to you. You child! Men like him don't bother with things like legality. They don't have to. You know why, boy-o? Power. Power like you couldn't even begin to imagine. Howard Hughes, he would just kill us. Hearst he would kill us and fuck everything we ever loved.

question: We're doing Hearst.
answer: You may think you know what you're talking about, kid, but believe me, you don't. You're talking about going into a battle you can never win on a battlefield so far above things like movies and Hollywood that Hearst won't even have to glance down when he crushes you. When he flicks you away with one finger. I'm talking about money and influence and evil beyond your capacity to imagine Hell.

question: So speaks the court jester.
answer: Fuck you

question: I expected more from you.
answer: Sorry to disappoint.

question: How does it feel, Mank? Going up to the palace and making all the lords and ladies laugh as you tell your little stories and beg for crumbs at the table? How does it feel being the ugly little monkey they keep to amuse themselves--?!
answer: It feels just fine, you pompous fuck-

question: I remember a man who wrote I He was a brilliant writer who dazzled me time and time again with his wit and insight--
answer: Don't do this

question: Where did he go? He hasn't had a screen credit in four years--
answer: Don't do this

question: --Because he has been so furiously busy wasting himself. Amusing his keepers. Because he is a sycophant! Because he has been thrown out of every studio in Hollywood and no one will hire him because he's a drunk- -!
answer: AND YOU'RE NOTHING BUT A GODDAMN PHONY! What is all this "Orson Welles" bullshit?! This boy genius crap?! What the fuck did you ever CREATE? You're just another goddamn ACTOR! Let me out.

question: Listen to me-
answer: Fuck you--

question: I am giving you the last chance you will ever have to be yourself again!
answer: I don't have it anymore?! When I was a kid I wanted to scorch the world too - - I had all kinda dreams about making great pictures and telling great stories. But all that's finished for me--

question: It doesn't have to be
answer: And yeah, sure, Hearst's a great subject. Been keeping notes on him for years for my ... great American novel. But I can't do it anymore. No studio's gonna hire me and I - -

answer: I can't do it. okay?! I drink too much -- I drink all the fucking time and I don't have it anymore. All that is over for me--

question: Look, Mank, this is our only chance
answer: He'll destroy us.

question: Then let him. What have we got to lose, you and I? Take my hand, Mank. And we'll dance one last time. We'll dance to the music of the angels. We'll make history. We'll scorch the earth. We will ... astonish them all.
answer: Thank God you don't write dialogue

question: So, who is he? We have to know him.
answer: Everyone sees someone different. That's what we show.

question: How?
answer: Like a jewel. Turn it in the light and a different facet is illuminated. Go

question: The key -- the key -- the clue -- what does this man recall on his death bed? Okay, Mank, you're dying. What's the last image that comes to you? Right now.
answer: This girl on a dock. White dress. Never said a word to her.

question: Why her?
answer: She was . . . innocent So when was our man innocent? Was there a moment early on -- of innocence and bliss? There must have been. Okay, you're dying - what do you think? Something you lost maybe? Something you can never get back?

question: All men love. But men like Hearst -- they don't bother with convention because--
answer: They don't have to.

question: He loves in his own way. On his conditions. Because those are the only conditions he has ever known. Hearst looks down at the world at his feet Everything has always been beneath him.
answer: And what does he see?

question: The people. When they pay him homage, he adores them. But when they have the ... audacity to question him. To doubt him. To embarrass him. Then he despises them.
answer: And when he looks up? What does he dream about? I'm ready to write it, Orson I know him The clatter of an old typewriter is heard. EXT/INT + Leiand

question: ... And I said, "Mr. Toland, you are the finest cinematographer in Hollywood, why would you desire to work with a stumbling neophyte?" And he replied, "Mr. Welles, the only way to learn anything new is to work with someone who doesn't know a damn thing."
answer: Priceless!

question: Hedda, this movie is going to look like no other picture ever made. Tome it's a question of truth and illusion. Don't you get tired of the errant falsity in motion pictures?

answer: Good God no! The character is a delicious amalgamation of various press barons--

question: A delicious amalgamation, is it?
answer: That's right. A symphony of those

question: Orson, hold on. Look into my eyes. Tell me you are not doing Hearst.
answer: I am not doing Hearst. It's 350 pages long.

question: I am not doing Hearst. It's 350 pages long.
answer: Yeah, but the margins are real wide.

question: It is 350 pages of ... ABSOLUTE INSPIRATION! Housey, get us a drink. I told you you could do this! How could you have ever doubted me!? You must never doubt me again!
answer: It's good, huh?

question: Good?! Good?! Words fail you at last! It's terrific! Now I'll have to do some shaping, of course, and some of the scenes aren't exactly . . . exactly . . .
answer: What?

question: Short enough. But this is a grand start And I think we need to change the name.
answer: The title?

question: No, AMERICAN is a blessed title directly sent from God's soul to your mind. We shall never change that! I mean the name of the publisher. Charles Foster Craig doesn't have the knives-out poetry I need. I was thinking about "Kane" -- you like that?
answer: Cain -- like the Bible guy?

question: K-A-N-E. One strong syllable. Kane I
answer: Craig is one syllable

question: But it's not a great syllable
answer: I --um-- I don't know if I should. I ain't been drinking since I started on this--

question: To my invaluable comrade Drink up!
answer: I'm out, aren't I? YOU FUCK! YOU SELFISH FUCK!

question: Jesus Christ --
answer: YOU CAN'T DO THIS TOME -- THIS WAS OUR STORY, REMEMBER? -- YOU AND ME AND GODDAMN EVERYONE ELSE - - REMEMBER THAT?! Pal from the studio sent this -- you see that?! What does it say?! WHAT DOES IT SAY ORSON?!

question: Get away from me-- It's obviously a mistake, Manki Some steno girl made a mistake, alright?!
answer: You can't do this to me--!

question: I fucking well can! I own your script and I can do anything I goddamn want. And don't forget for one minute that I took your 350 pages of drunken rambling and I made a movie out of them -- and now I've got to shoot the bastard. So thank you very much, I have all I need. And you can stop calling me.
answer: I hope you choke on it. I hope it kills you.

question: This is supposed ta be Siam or some such. Some kinda lousy B-B-Balinese temple. This look like a temple to you? I can't see it myself--
answer: Darling, I talked to Millicent. She said no

question: There. That's right.
answer: She's a Catholic. She says it would put her soul in peril. Divorce is a very serious sin, apparently.

question: Nuts. She only cares about the money. She thinks I'll make you cut her out of the w-w-w-w... will.
answer: I'm so sorry.

question: It's an awful title, of course, but I can't think of anything better. Someone came up with A SEA OF UPTURNED FACES -- which has a nice, grand ring to it -- and I thought of JOHN CITIZEN, USA but that strikes me as a bit Warner Brothers. Or, God forbid, Capraesque. I suppose AMERICAN will do for now but-- Pardon?
answer: CITIZEN KANE There's your title.

question: A "Z" and a "K" in the title. That would draw the eye. For the poster. I like that THE PRISONER OF ZENDA had a "Z" and a "P" and that worked--
answer: Now look, Orson, let's not get ahead of ourselves. The budget projections on this--

question: I know, I know! But what more can you expect of me?! I have pared this story down to the marrow to save money but to cut more would be to--!
answer: Listen, get off your horse with me. You know I've stuck by you since the beginning of time it seems like, while the stockholders in New York were ready to cut and run and everyone else in Hollywood was set to toss me in a rubber room. But your contract stipulates a max budget of 500 thousand. This one's gonna come in at 750 thousand. What do we do about that? Now don't have a fit -- but I want you to think again about doing WAR OF THE WORLDS-

question: Jesus
answer: Do WAR OF THE WORLDS as a feature and everyone's happy. You make some money and New York's happy and you have a track record and then we'll move on to

question: Please don't ask me to do this.
answer: It's the safe bet, Orson. There's nothing wrong with that.

question: George, I want you to let me make this movie because I need to make it. And I don't really know It's your decision, George. If you look into my eyes right now and say, go make WAR OF THE WORLDS, I will. I'll make it. And, yes, it'll make you money.
answer: If it'll get you the hell out of my office, go ahead and make the picture. Say thank you, Orson. For the title

question: Ah, it's a grand title.
answer: Like it would kill him to say thank you

question: We're going to do this because it's going to be fun.
answer: "Rosebud? I'll tell you about Rosebud.

question: Again.
answer: "Rosebud? I'll tell you about Rosebud.

question: Again.

question: Again

question: Again Well, that didn't really work It is the most important line of the picture. You will weave the magic of "Rosebud" in a single word - - you will say the word in such a way as to impart to us the mystery of it. It is a divine and sinister mystery worthy only of your talent. In this one word the movie soars or falls. Once more, I beg you.
answer: "Rosebud? I'll tell you about Rosebud."

question: And I'm looking at them -- and they're all looking at me and I don't know who should pour the tea. '
answer: Uh huh.

question: I just can't . . see it anymore I want you back
answer: Fuck you. You wanted me out. I'm out.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: I don't care.

question: This is the shooting script we've been using every day. It's just like we always said it would be
answer: Too late, kid.

question: Did I ever tell you about my father?
answer: I don't give a shit about-

question: He was a drunk. And he was my father and I was ashamed of him. He showed me the world, he took me with him everywhere -- Europe, China -- and he was so proud of me. But he would drink and he would get ...embarrassing. And I began to resent him Because I was so ... sparkling, you see. When I finally saw him again, he was in a coffin. I was fifteen. And all of a sudden he wasn't that embarrassing drunk anymore ... he was the man who showed me the world. Just like you, Mank.
answer: So you've lost it? Don't know who should pour the tea.

question: Yeah
answer: Orson ... just cut the goddamn tea

question: Okay
answer: I been thinking about the beach scene. You done that yet?

answer: Good -- cause I was thinking that we're starting the scene too late... Cause if we don't show Susan watching Kane more then we're not building the right tension into the scene. See, she's gotta know that...

answer: Spare me the aria, I know what you want--

question: I need my shoes in total focus right here and also Joe back there--!
answer: I know what you want but it can't be done!

question: Take apart the fucking camera rig -- we could get a few more inches down and then tilt up--
answer: Orson -- we can't get the fucking camera any fucking lower so find another fucking shot!

question: Come on, Gregg! We'll tear out this floor!
answer: It's midnight, why don't we pick it up tomorrow?

question: "Well, if you got drunk to talk to me about Miss Alexander, don't bother. I'm not interested. I've set back the sacred cause of reform, is that it? All right, if that's the way they want it, the people have made their choice. It's obvious the people prefer Jim Gettys to me."
answer: "You talk about the people as if you owned them. As though they belonged to you. As long as I can remember, you've talked about--" Orson, I am so goddamn tired--

question: Keep filming.
answer: I can't remember the lines!

question: Then make them up! You're drunk and you're angry. This is the chance you've been waiting for, boy. Tell that son of a bitch just what you think of him!

question: You're not going to get another chance, boy! Look right at the monster and you tell him--
answer: "You don't care about anything except you. You just want to persuade people that you love them so much that they ought to love you back. Only you want love on your own terms. "

question: This is an abomination There's no music and--
answer: They've all seen a rough cut

question: The magazines are one thing -- but Hedda! Why did we have to let her come?!
answer: When Hedda says "I'm coming" you mix a lot of martinis and you pray.

question: Here? As in right outside the door? Well, send her in! Shit
answer: Schaefer, I gotta see this Welles picture

question: Louella, hello, I was just fixing a drink, would you like--?
answer: You drink at 10 am, do you?

question: No -- no -- I mean--
answer: I wanna see the picture today

answer: Cut the malarkey, buddy. The boss himself wants me to see the picture today.

question: He personally asked you to?
answer: That's right

question: Hearst?
answer: Uh-huh I'll be back at noon. Set it up in screening room four.

question: Oh god
answer: It's all you. It has the political campaigns and the mining fortune and the war with Pulitzer and the castle. And ... Marion.

question: It's all you. It has the political campaigns and the mining fortune and the war with Pulitzer and the castle. And ... Marion.

question: The jigsaw puzzles and the, urn, career -- the man spending a fortune to make her a star -- only it's opera and not movies. And...
answer: Yes?

question: The drinking.
answer: So my life is a subject for mockery. All of it. Every detail. Every personal detail. Thank you for your time

question: Thank you, sir. She begins to leave
answer: Miss Parsons, I have one additional question for you.

question: Sir?
answer: Why did we not know about this sooner?

question: Sir?
answer: I pay you a good deal of money to be my eyes and ears in Hollywood, do I not? If you cannot provide this simple service you are of no use to me.

question: Sir, I-
answer: Please be quiet.

question: He lied to me He looked into my face and told me it wasn't about you.
answer: And how do you feel when you are lied to?

question: I want blood
answer: Good. Retain that feeling. Let it nourish you from this day forth. It shall nourish us both

question: Louis
answer: Randolph!

question: Hope you don't mind my popping in--
answer: No -- no -- sit down, please

question: What a wretched place this is. I can't come to town without feeling filthy. You really must buy that parcel of land by the castle and come north. Quite. And this is why I came to visit. Have you heard about this CITIZEN KANE picture?
answer: Over at RKO?

question: Mm. Not a very good picture I am told.
answer: Uh-hub.

question: Apparently it details the exploits of a publisher like myself. Entirely too much like myself. Do you follow so far?
answer: Yeah

question: I can't see how the release of that picture will do anyone any good, really. Say, while I'm in town why don't we play 18 holes at Bel Air? Or maybe just nine. Do you have time for a round today? And maybe we could get Mr. Warner and Mr. Goldwyn and Mr. Cohn and Mr. Selznick to play as well.
answer: You know that can't happen.

question: Oh, why is that? Why is that, Louis?
answer: Bel Air is restricted.

question: Oh, that's right. How silly of me to have forgotten. I sometimes forget that you're all Jews. Lots of people forget that. If they ever knew it. See what you can do about this CITIZEN KANE picture, won't you?
answer: Yeah

question: That's right, fella, no Hearst paper will run an RKO ad until you agree that CITIZEN KANE will never see the light of day.
answer: Louella, please, be reasonable, I understand you have problems with Orson's picture but maybe we can work something out--

question: Nix, sweetie. You shelve it
answer: Oh for God's sake, Louella-

question: And Mr. Hearst has authorized me to tell you that you're looking at the most beautiful lawsuit in history if you release this picture. He'll bleed your little studio dry and you can all go on back to New York and do Shakespeare with the Boy Wonder.
answer: Can I talk to Hearst?

question: The Journal was pretty harsh to Roosevelt today.
answer: You oughta lay off him -- he is the p-p-president, after all.

question: He is a Bolshevik. He will have us at war by the end of the year. I think I'm going to run that wheelchair picture.
answer: Don't Whaddaya think?

question: Thank you, Joseph.
answer: How bad is it?

question: Nothing for you to worry about, darling
answer: Pops

question: The S.E.C. has turned down my request for relief on the debts.
answer: How much?

question: It's not really--
answer: How much?

question: 125 million.
answer: We're 125 million dollars in debt?

question: Yes.
answer: How does one get 125 million dollars in debt?

question: We open on Monument Valley. Those towering stalagmites reaching up like pleading fingers to God. A single figure treads the arid plains. The crimson sun is behind him so his shadow stretches toward us. He is a simple man wearing a simple robe. A profoundly quiet and sad man. Who is he? Who is he, Gregg?
answer: Oh, no--

question: Yes!
answer: He's Christ?

question: I'm Christ
answer: You want to do the life of Jesus?

question: Yes! Vibrant and modern and stark like a Picasso sketch drawn to flashes of lightning I We shoot the whole thing in the gallant American West--
answer: Hey, kid. Gregg.

question: Mank, sit down. You missed the opening of the new picture but I'll go back--
answer: No, you gotta hear this-

question: Sorry, you keep at it, old boy.
answer: You read Louella?

question: No, but I can imagine. What am I today? A "puny upstart" or a "spoiled dilettante" -- no, she wouldn't know how to spell that
answer: "And how is the country to feel when this industry continues to employ bedraggled foreigners and swarthy refugees instead of real Americans? Doesn't Hollywood know there's a Depression on? Don't real Americans deserve work?"

question: Well, at least she's off KANE today
answer: No she's not. Don't you get it, ya lunk? She's using code language to the studio bosses. "Bedraggled foreigners and swarthy refugees" -- who the hell do you think she's talking about?

question: Hedy Lamarr?
answer: Jews. She's talking about Jews. Who owns this town? Who runs every goddamn studio? The tribe, baby. These fuckers hear the word "Jew" and they start sweating. Like Ester Williams' pool they start sweating.

question: So they're Jews. . .
answer: This is just the first shot. Maestro. Sooner or later she's gonna use the word. And all those boys know that there is only one thing this country hates more than the coloreds and that's the Jews.

question: Christ.
answer: Me, I'm proud to be a Jew, I got no problem. You don't like it, fuck you. But with these guys it's like a dirty word. All they wanna be is good red- white-and-blue Americans, and the way they see it you can't be a good American and a Jew. So Sam Goldfish becomes Sam Goldwyn and David Selznick becomes David 0. Selznick -- like anyone's gonna think he's Irish for fuck's sake--

question: What does this have to do with--?
answer: Believe you me, they're gonna do anything -- and I mean absolutely anything -- to stop that word from gettin' out.

question: What?! Are they going to kill me? Is that what they're going to do?!
answer: Let me tell you a story, son So this was 1924, right? Hearst was throwing a birthday party for Thomas Ince, the old movie producer. They were all on the old man's yacht taking a nice jaunt from Pedro down to San Diego. Real foggy night it was. This was Hearst, Marion, Ince, Charlie Chaplin, Louella, the usual gorillas. So Hearst notices Marion slip off with Chaplin -- she was screwing everyone then -- and the old man goes nuts. Grabs his revolver and starts shooting. Just like Tom Mix, standing there blasting away through the fog. Boom - - boom -- boom -- and Thomas Ince takes a bullet through the head. So now there's this dead guy lying on the deck. You'll see how this could be quite an embarrassment. So the empire goes into action. Nice and quiet and Ince was cremated lickety-split. No inquest and no police. It was right after this that Hearst gives Louella her life-time contract. Just to keep her all hush-hush. If he had known about KANE before you made it, you'd be dead already.

question: It's too late. The movie's made
answer: They won't let it out. Not Hearst. Not the other studio heads--

question: You wrote the damn thing, Mank Aren't you going to fight for it?!
answer: I told you this was going to happen! I told you he was going to come after us! So we took the chance anyway and we lost. That's how it goes, okay? I got my check, kid, and so did you -- and that's what it's all about -- so fuck it and move on.

question: Switch it off SWITCH IT OFF Would everyone please leave
answer: Well -- he got us, didn't he? She stands and goes quickly to pour a drink. A forced laugh Nailed us, hub? The crazy old man and his whore.

question: Marion--
answer: Bought and p-p-paid for. Just like one of his goddamn statues. Well at least in the movie he married her!

question: This picture--
answer: I am not that woman. I mean he's even got the goddamn jigsaw puzzles Why did he do that to us?

question: So what do we got here, L.B.? We got faggots and commies and junkies. We got movie stars screwing niggers and little girls. We got killers and perverts and whores. We got MGM and Warner Brothers and Columbia and Disney and Fox. We got Jews We got Hollywood.
answer: What do you want?

question: Kill CITIZEN KANE.
answer: How?

question: Then you explain it to me?!
answer: There's nothing to explain

question: A million dollars a year on art and st-st-statues and there's nothing to explain?!
answer: I will not defend my life to you--

question: I'm not asking you to defend anything. But we're in a pickle and we gotta talk about it.
answer: We are in no "pickle" -- as you would euphemistically have it.

question: You gotta wake up now. Pops.
answer: There is nothing to discuss-

question: You don't have any money left, okay?! That's the truth. I don't wanna say it, nobody else will say it, but it's the truth. You spent it all. You can't buy the Tribune in Chicago -- you can't buy ^ g-g- goddamn thing. Now you better face up to it--
answer: You are being typically theatrical, Marion. I need the Tribune to--

question: You don't need it! That's the problem you always think you need everything-- That -- did you need that? How much did that cost?
answer: It's 12th Century. From Deauville -- in France.

question: I know where Deauville is for C-C-Christ's sake.
answer: You needn't use that language with me

question: Did you need it? Did you need any of it?
answer: I wanted it

question: There's a different between want and
answer: Not for me.

question: But why? Just so you can show it all off -- just so everyone can see what a b-b-big man you are?!
answer: That's right. You've captured me exactly. Goodnight.

question: You will not walk out on me
answer: You are repellant when you drink.

question: Tough shit. We need to t-t-talk about this--
answer: You are slovenly and unattractive and I won't t-t-t-tolerate it.

question: Fuck you, Mr. Kane.
answer: I will not have this in my home.

question: I just want to understand--
answer: No, you don't. You want to condemn me, like everyone else. You want to point to the pathetic, old man grown lunatic with his spending -- trapped in his ridiculous castle -- still fighting old battles he will never win with Pulitzer and Roosevelt and Hollywood--

question: I don't want you to--
answer: There is nothing to understand but this

question: When I met him I was just 20. And he was 55. I saw the gold ring and just grabbed on. And he was going to make me a star.
answer: And he did.

question: When I was making movies I kept begging him to let me do comedies. Silly stuff, you know. But Pops doesn't get comedy too well so he kept putting me in all those godawful p-p-period dramas. I did my best but, well, you know me
answer: Sure

question: Thing that bothers me now, though, looking back is that I really think I could have been something ... special.
answer: Thinking like that is only gonna drive you nuts You were a great star and you had a good run. That oughta be enough.

question: Yeah. But all of a sudden it's not You know this CITIZEN KANE picture? About Pops and everything?
answer: Uh-huh

question: The character that's supposed to be me, Susan Alexander--
answer: Marion, everyone knows you're not like that--

question: But I am That's the killer, honey. It's hell when you gotta look back and say, goddamn, what I could have been.
answer: May I help you?

question: I, um, need an estimate on some jewelry I might wish to sell. But d-d-discretion is very important to me b-b-because I don't want anyone t-t-to, um, know that--
answer: Excuse me, I hope this isn't rude, but aren't you Marion Davies?

question: Yes.
answer: Well, this is a great pleasure. Miss Davies! I just saw that ENCHANTMENT is playing at a the Tivoli, the revival house in Santa Monica. That was a fine picture!

question: Thank you-
answer: Not one of them today has what you had, Miss Davies. Not one of them.

question: Thank you -- b-b-but I'd really like t-t-to--
answer: Of course, of course. How can we be of service?

question: As I said I have some j-j-j-j- that I might wish t-t-to sell and I wanted an estimate--
answer: Surely My pleasure, Miss Davies.. My Lord. . .

question: What do you want me to do, Orson? Radio City won't premiere the picture. Louella threatened them with some bullshit about
answer: Then find another theater

question: You don't think I've tried? No one is willing to open the picture
answer: Then we'll open it in Detroit or Dallas or Kalamazoo for God's sake! We'll show it in goddamn circus tents and--!

question: Listen to me. The press ban is killing us and the distributors won't book it. And meantime I'm dealing with the stockholders in New York who are scared shitless -- and I'm this far from getting fired myself -- and you don't have a friend in the world but me right now. So you have got to trust that I'll do what I can to--
answer: "Do what you can"?! That's not good enough I

question: Well it' s all you've got !
answer: You're with them, aren't you? You're going to bury my movie. They bought you!

question: For Christ's sake, shut up--
answer: Why don't you just have the guts to admit it

question: How dare you talk to me like that! Do you think I'm like all the rest of those pirates?! Like Mayer and Warner? Is that what you think--?!
answer: It's just that my movie is so-

question: "Your movie" -- I am so sick of that! It's your movie -- but it's his life! Did you ever think about that?! Did you ever think about that old man and Marion having to watch as you tore them apart?!
answer: I didn't--

question: Do you every think for one second that you might have some responsibility for what you're doing?! For cutting and slashing everything in your way so you can have your goddamn movie?!
answer: That soulless monster gets no tears from me.

question: Who the fuck are you trying to kid? You are that soulless monster. Recognize It's Tara. From GONE WITH THE WIND
answer: It's ... sad

question: Mr. Zanuck ... Mr. Warner ... Mr. Cohn Mr. Disney .. . Mr. Goldwyn . . . Mr. Selznick.
answer: He's a fucking punk, why does Hearst give a shit?

question: It's enough that he does In a New York minute Who isn't hurting already? All this Jew talk and these Communist rumors. Look, he's boycotting RKO ads right now -- but how long before he takes on Warners or Fox or Columbia? And if Hearst goes public with all this filthy private lives stuff, Hollywood's sunk. He's got us nailed. Dates. Times. Photographs for God's sake. He's got you so tied in with J. Edgar Hoover and America First that you might as well put on a brown shirt and kiss those happy little kiddies so-long.
answer: Who the fuck cares? Get off the soapbox--

question: David-
answer: Your son-in-law meshuaena. Relax, Walt, at least he don't have you screwing Snow White. I got fucking Errol Flynn on my payroll!

question: "Ev'ry summer I will sail the sea, On my little yacht the Normandie, Pet my little dachshund friends, Kiss Louella's big rear end, Just disgustingly rich. "Perfumed and scented, Slightly demented-- Just disgustingly rich George- -!
answer: This isn' t some kinda fucking game! You know how many people RKO employs?! You know how many people depend on what we do for a living?!

question: I really think you're
answer: You wanna commit suicide, fine! You got some death- wish, fine! But you will not drag this company down with you!

question: It was a -joke, George
answer: There are no jokes! There are people making a living. There is food on the table! Where did this money come from?

question: There are no jokes! There are people making a living. There is food on the table! Where did this money come from?
answer: It came. 800,000 dollars fully covers the production budget and a little more. Hell, George, you even make a profit on the deal.

question: Very generous
answer: And we gotta be clear here. I need the negative and every existing print.

question: To do what?
answer: That's for me to decide.

question: You're going to destroy it
answer: No, maybe put it on the shelf until the old man kicks it.

question: You're lying to me.
answer: We already made the same offer to the stockholders.

question: You talked to New York?
answer: Yes

question: You talked to Mr. Swanbeck?
answer: Yes

question: Get out
answer: You're bettin' on an inside straight this time. You'll never pull it off.

question: Get out.
answer: This picture, George, it'll just break your heart.

question: George! Enter And Behold You're not still mad at me, I hope
answer: No, we're jake. But listen-

question: Look, not a single scene shot in the studio! We've found natural locations for the whole story--
answer: Hold on a sec. I got news. We finally found somewhere to premiere KANE but--

question: I told you! Where? Grauman's? El Capitan? Or did Radio City come crawling back?
answer: The Palace in New York. But Orson there's something else. I think you better sit down

question: I don't want to sit
answer: The bosses -- the other studios -- they want to buy the film and destroy it. They came to me with an offer. 800,000 for the negative and all the prints. And they went to the stockholders in New York.

question: Six of spades Six of spades Today. Today a man from Germany invaded Greece. He has already swallowed Poland and Denmark and Norway and Belgium. He is bombing London as I speak. Everywhere this man goes he crushes the life and the freedom of his subjects. He sews yellow stars onto their lapels. He takes their voices.
answer: We open on May 1st. Orson, what you said in there. Did you mean it?

question: Does it matter? They believed it
answer: Orson. Yes. It matters.

question: Mr. Hearst, we've met once before, my name is Orson Welles and I've got a movie opening tomorrow night at the Palace. I would be pleased to get you tickets.
answer: I wonder. Do you have any idea what you have done?

question: Do you?
answer: Intimately. For every sin you have placed on my head I could give you a hundred others. I have been swimming in blood my entire life. But I retain a belief, perhaps you will think it old fashioned, undoubtedly you will, but I believe that private lives should not be public property.

question: Elegant words, sir, when you have made your name and your fortune on slander and innuendo and gossip. In your papers you taught the world how to look under every rock. I learned at the knee of the master.
answer: So where does that leave us, Mr. Welles? What kind of sad future are we two making? A future where men will do anything to sell their newspapers and their movies? A future where no price is too high for fame and power? When we will all scratch each other to pieces just to be heard?

question: So ain't this just the bee's knees? The high muckey-mucks dolled up all Aztec-like for the human sacrifice.
answer: You gonna watch?

question: Hell, I know how it ends. Hey, Rosebud's the sled!
answer: Mank!

question: Oh God. . .
answer: Relax, George. It's gonna go great. Trust me. Have I ever lied to you?

question: You know something, Orson, you haven't done anything but lie to me from the moment we met. But, ya know, I'd do it again in a second.
answer: It was fun, wasn't it?

question: It was the best, kid
answer: So, on to the Life Of Christ!
